variant.question: Two aircraft are vectored to different FLs but the F/O of one aircraft sets in the wrong FL on the autopilot, so both aircraft are climbing to same FL320 on a converging course. Neither ATC nor the commander detects the problem. The result is a TCAS warning and near collision. Which of the following types of errors were committed?

options.text: Handling errors by the F/O, procedural error by the commander and ATC.
Handling error by the F/O, communication errors by the commander and ATC.
Communication errors by the F/O, commander, and ATC.
Communication errors by the F/O and ATC only.

variant.question: Which answer lists only sub-categories of errors according to the TEM concept?

options.text: Aircraft handling, procedural
Organisation, environment
Ground navigation, aircraft configuration
Aircraft situation, communication

variant.question: According to James Reason, what are the different categories of error?

options.text: Slips, lapses, mistakes, and violations.
Faults, defects, weaknesses, and oversights.
Failures, omissions, deficiencies, and flaws.
Defects, deficiencies, ambiguities, and anomalies.

variant.question:
Waiting for takeoff on the runway, a pilot is informed by the tower that the tail wind component is 12 kt
According to the manual, the limitation is 10 kt max
The pilot makes a decision to take-off anyway, as the runway is long
What type of error is this known as?

options.text: A violation.
This is neither an error or a violation – the pilot is using his initiative.
A decision error.
An error of reasoning.

Knowledge-based

variant.question: Select the correct statement regarding human errors.

options.text: An error can be described as the mismatch between the pilot’s intention and the result of his/her actions.
Representational errors are those in which the pilot has properly identified the situation and is familiar with the procedure.
All errors are avoidable through continuous and thorough training.
A violation is an error which is always involuntary.

the human/system interface and have a delayed effect

variant.question: Which of the following statements fits best the concept of latent error? Latent errors:

options.text: have been present in the system for a certain length of time and are difficult to understand as a result of the time lag between the generation and the occurrence of the error.
are mainly associated with the behaviour of front-line operators and are only detected after advanced problem-solving.
are rarely made by front-line operators and are consequently readily identified and detected by the monitoring, detection and warning links.
rapidly may be detected via their immediate consequences on the action in progress.

variant.question: What is correct regarding active errors? An active error is:

options.text: Committed by the operator (e.g. pilot, air traffic controller) and has an immediate effect.
NOT common at the human-system interface and difficult to detect as it usually occurs in a complex system of uncontrolled and involuntary deviations.
Produced either by a front-line operator (e.g. pilot) or by a remote operator (e.g. maintenance engineer) and the effects are hidden or have a delayed impact.
The consequence of the application of a bad rule or poor application of a good rule by aircraft designers and/or manufacturers.

variant.question:
A pilot is distracted by a failure of his/her navigation equipment and consequently does not execute a planned turn. Afterwards, he/she lands at his/her intermediate airport and checks the weather at his/her final destination. As the weather looks good, he/she decides to take off without loading additional fuel. When he/she encounters an unexpected headwind, he/she barely makes it to his/her final destination without any fuel left. What were the errors committed?(1) Forgotten turn: lapse 
 (2) Forgotten turn: violation 
 (3) Forgotten turn: slip 
 (4) Forgotten turn: rule-based error 
 (5) Fuel: knowledge-based error 
 (6) Fuel: lapse 
 (7) Fuel: violation

options.text: 3 and 5.
1 and 5.
4 and 7.
2 and 7.

options.text: helpful
stressful

variant.question: The crew of a business jet have completed the pre-flight checks and are ready to start the engines. The passenger arrives late and the crew complete the start and taxi checks. In order to keep to the original time for take-off the PIC requests an immediate take-off clearance which is granted. To save time, the PIC also completes the pre-take-off checks from memory while taxiing and does NOT use the checklist. After take-off, the crew realise that the pitot heat (an item on the checklist) had been forgotten. What types of error are shown in this scenario?

options.text: The PIC's decision to complete the pre-take-off checks from memory was a violation. As a result, a lapse occured in the execution, which was failing to check the pitot heat setting.
By failing to follow the normal checklist procedure, the PIC made a mistake and also an error of judgement. This resulted in an execution slip when the pitot heat check was omitted
Failing to follow the challenge and reply checklist procedure was a rule based error. The consequent failure to check the pitot heat setting was a lapse in execution
The PIC made a rule-based error by NOT following the normal checklist procedure. In addition, he/she made a knowledge-based mistake by failing to check the pitot heat setting.

variant.question: According to Rasmussen's model, errors in rule-based control mode are of the following type(s):

options.text: errors of technical knowledge.
routine errors.
creative errors.
handling errors.

variant.question: Errors may be classified into two major categories: active and latent. Which one of the definitions below relates to a latent error?

options.text: A system containing unrecognised faults, which become evident under specific circumstances.
An error that arises from inadequate knowledge or experience.
An issue that stems from a failure in applying an inappropriate rule.
An event that occurs immediately before an incident or accident.

variant.question: Human errors are frequent and may take several forms:

options.text: An error can be described as the mismatch between the pilot's intention and the result of his/her actions.
An error of intention is an error of routine.
A violation is an error which is always involuntary.
Representational errors in which the pilot has properly identified the situation and is familiar with the procedure.

variant.question:
The crew of an Airbus A320 is flying towards an airport in severe thunderstorms and reported wind shear conditions. Due to several aircraft going around, delays are to be expected and the crew is cleared into a holding pattern. Preoccupied with the weather ahead of them, the crew fails to notice that they have accidentally pulled back the thrust levers too far, disabling the autothrottle. As airspeed drops, and aerodynamic buffet sets in, it is interpreted by the crew as entry into turbulence. When the aircraft actually stalls, the crew is convinced to have encountered wind shear and performs the appropriate escape manoeuvre. As the manoeuvre includes applying full thrust, the crew can successfully recover from the stall and land safely.
What is correct regarding the initial error?

options.text: The error was due to internal factors.
Applying the SHELL model, the error was due to environmental issues.
It is a latent error, because it could only manifest itself because of the wind shear conditions.
It can be regarded as a violation, as approaches in wind shear are forbidden by most companies’ SOPs.

variant.question:
The crew of an Airbus A300 is flying towards an airport in severe thunderstorms and reported wind shear conditions. Due to several aircraft going around, delays have to be expected and the crew is cleared into a holding pattern. Preoccupied with the weather ahead of them, the crew fails to notice that they have accidentally pulled back the thrust levers too far, disabling the autothrottle. As airspeed drops, and aerodynamic buffet sets in, it is interpreted by the crew as entry into turbulence. When the aircraft actually stalls, the crew is convinced to have encountered wind shear and performs the appropriate escape manoeuvre. As the manoeuvre includes applying full thrust, the crew can successfully recover from the stall and land safely.
Which of the following statements is correct with regard to the initial error.

options.text: The error was due to internal factors.
Applying the SHELL model, the error was due to environmental issues.
It can be regarded as a violation, as approaches in wind shear are forbidden by most companies’ SOPs.
It is a latent error, because it could only manifest itself because of the wind shear conditions.

variant.question:
The analysis of aviation accidents distinguishes between active and latent failures

options.text: The airline management decides to cut costs in all departments, including the flight training department, due to the global economic downturn
The aircraft technician fails to follow all the steps on the job card and forgets to reconnect the altimeter’s static port during a routine maintenance check.
After the leading aircraft slows down more than anticipated on final approach, the air traffic controller realizes too late that minimum separation was violated.
The pilot correctly reads back the new altitude assignment during an en-route climb but proceeds to set it incorrectly in the autopilot’s mode control panel.

not common at the human-system interface and difficult to detect as it usually occurs in a complex system of uncontrolled and involuntary deviations

variant.question: How can the error chain help pilots to prevent accidents?

options.text: Recognition of the presence of the elements of the error chain does not in itself eliminate the risk of an accident. Instead, it serves as a warning to the crew that they must take correct action to manage the progress of flight in the face of rising risks.
Recognition of the presence of the elements of the error chain will eliminate the risk of an accident.
Correct use of the error chain will - in itself - prevent most accidents.
The error chain can help flight crew minimise the effects after a serious error has caused a problem.

Jerky attitude flying due to lack of sleep.

variant.question: Which of the following statements is a good example of a latent error:

options.text: Management make cutbacks, including training budgets, due to the global economic downturn.

variant.question: Analyse the following exchange between a pilot and an air traffic controller (ATC): - ATC: Fastair 213, squawk **6135** - Pilot: Squawk **6315**, Fastair 213 - ATC: Fastair 213, descend level 320

options.text: ATC made a mistake, because the incorrect readback of the squawk was not corrected
ATC made a mistake, because a pilot must not be given a new squawk when he has other tasks to perform in order to prevent overload
The pilot made a mistake, because active listening requires him to correctly receive and read back the assigned squawk
If the pilot sets the correct squawk and ATC verifies the radar target, there is no mistake made in this conversation

variant.question:
The most fatal crash in aviation history occurred on March 29th **1977** at Tenerife Los Rodeos Airport, when a KLM Boeing 747 collided with a Pan American Boeing 747 in almost zero visibility conditions in severe fog.
In the course leading to the accident, the KLM aircraft received its route clearance, which was read back by the First Officer, finishing by saying “We are now ready for take-off”. The controller’s reply was “OK, stand by for take-off”; however, the KLM crew only received the “OK” part as the rest of the sentence was cut off by a simultaneous transmission from another aircraft on the same frequency (interference). The KLM captain interpreted the “OK” as a take-off clearance and started his take-off run. However, at that time, the Pan American Boeing 747 was still taxiing down the runway, leading to the fatal collision.
State which type of communication and associated disadvantage are illustrated by the above accident.

options.text: Explicit communication. Since it was interrupted, it should have required communication with the controller.
Explicit communication. It is inherently open to interpretation by either the flight crew or the controller.
Implicit communication. It is susceptible to technical limitation; in this case, to multiple transmissions on the communication frequency.
Implicit communication. It can lead to confusion in case of conflicts between the verbal and non-verbal portion of the message.

hardware
checklists
